text:
problem with transpose is that it transposes everything, e.g., I have a matrix of matrices, and transpose acts on both the inner and outer indices

I could write a transpose to just return a view of the outer transposed matrices, just wasn’t sure if someone else already did it

elements.text:
problem with transpose is that it transposes everything, e.g., I have a matrix of matrices, and transpose acts on both the inner and outer indices

I could write a transpose to just return a view of the outer transposed matrices, just wasn’t sure if someone else already did it

text:
to clarify - transpose works recursively on arrays of arrays
```julia> A = [[1 2; 3 4], [5 6; 7 8]]
2-element Array{Array{Int64,2},1}:
 [1 2; 3 4]
 [5 6; 7 8]

julia> transpose(A)
1×2 Transpose{Transpose{Int64,Array{Int64,2}},Array{Array{Int64,2},1}}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [5 7; 6 8]```

elements.text: to clarify - transpose works recursively on arrays of arrays

text:
I coded up something to do the “block transpose” behavior I wanted
`reverse_CartesianIndex(ij) = CartesianIndex(reverse(ij.I))`
`transpose_blocks(A) = view(A,reverse_CartersianIndex.(CartesianIndices(A)))`

```julia> A = [i*reshape(1:4,2,2) for i = 1:2, j = 1:2]
2×2 Array{Array{Int64,2},2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [1 3; 2 4]
 [2 6; 4 8]  [2 6; 4 8]

julia> transpose_blocks(A)
2×2 view(::Array{Array{Int64,2},2}, CartesianIndex{2}[CartesianIndex(1, 1) CartesianIndex(2, 1); CartesianIndex(1, 2) CartesianIndex(2, 2)]) with eltype Array{Int64,2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [2 6; 4 8]
 [1 3; 2 4]  [2 6; 4 8]```

elements.text: I coded up something to do the “block transpose” behavior I wanted

julia> A = [i*reshape(1:4,2,2) for i = 1:2, j = 1:2]
2×2 Array{Array{Int64,2},2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [1 3; 2 4]
 [2 6; 4 8]  [2 6; 4 8]

julia> transpose_blocks(A)
2×2 view(::Array{Array{Int64,2},2}, CartesianIndex{2}[CartesianIndex(1, 1) CartesianIndex(2, 1); CartesianIndex(1, 2) CartesianIndex(2, 2)]) with eltype Array{Int64,2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [2 6; 4 8]
 [1 3; 2 4]  [2 6; 4 8]

text:
So you're in put looks like this:
```julia> A = Matrix{Matrix}(undef, 2,2)
2×2 Array{Array{T,2} where T,2}:
 #undef  #undef
 #undef  #undef

julia> A[1,1] = reshape(1:4,2,2); A[2,1] = reshape(5:8,2,2); A[1,2] = reshape(9:12,2,2); A[2,2] = reshape(13:16,2,2)
2×2 reshape(::UnitRange{Int64}, 2, 2) with eltype Int64:
 13  15
 14  16

julia> A
2×2 Array{Array{T,2} where T,2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [9 11; 10 12]
 [5 7; 6 8]  [13 15; 14 16]```

elements.text: So you're in put looks like this:

julia> A = Matrix{Matrix}(undef, 2,2)
2×2 Array{Array{T,2} where T,2}:
 #undef  #undef
 #undef  #undef

julia> A[1,1] = reshape(1:4,2,2); A[2,1] = reshape(5:8,2,2); A[1,2] = reshape(9:12,2,2); A[2,2] = reshape(13:16,2,2)
2×2 reshape(::UnitRange{Int64}, 2, 2) with eltype Int64:
 13  15
 14  16

julia> A
2×2 Array{Array{T,2} where T,2}:
 [1 3; 2 4]  [9 11; 10 12]
 [5 7; 6 8]  [13 15; 14 16]

text: the order of concatenation?

What you want in the end is this:
```julia> hcat(vcat(A[1,1],A[2,1]), vcat(A[2,1],A[2,2]))
4×4 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  3   5   7
 2  4   6   8
 5  7  13  15
 6  8  14  16```

elements.text: What you want in the end is this:

text: yes. my workaround was to pass a view of `A` with the indices transposed to `hvcat`

elements.text: yes. my workaround was to pass a view of

text:
```julia> function vhcat(cols::Tuple{Vararg{Int64,N}}, xs::AbstractMatrix{T}...) where {T,N}
           cols_cs = (1,cumsum(cols)[1:end-1]...)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - 1) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end
vhcat (generic function with 1 method)

julia> vhcat( (2,2), A[:]... )
4×4 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  3   5   7
 2  4   6   8
 5  7   9  11
 6  8  10  12```

elements.text:
julia> function vhcat(cols::Tuple{Vararg{Int64,N}}, xs::AbstractMatrix{T}...) where {T,N}
           cols_cs = (1,cumsum(cols)[1:end-1]...)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - 1) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end
vhcat (generic function with 1 method)

julia> vhcat( (2,2), A[:]... )
4×4 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  3   5   7
 2  4   6   8
 5  7   9  11
 6  8  10  12

text:
or more general:
```julia> function vhcat(cols::Tuple{Vararg{Int64,N}}, xs::AbstractVecOrMat{T}...) where {T,N}
           cols_cs = (1,cumsum(cols)[1:end-1]...)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - 1) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end
vhcat (generic function with 2 methods)```

elements.text:
julia> function vhcat(cols::Tuple{Vararg{Int64,N}}, xs::AbstractVecOrMat{T}...) where {T,N}
           cols_cs = (1,cumsum(cols)[1:end-1]...)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - 1) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end
vhcat (generic function with 2 methods)

           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - 1) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )

text:
```julia> function vhcat(cols::Tuple{Vararg{Int64,N}}, xs::AbstractVecOrMat{T}...) where {T,N}
           cols_cs = cumsum(cols)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - cols[i]) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end```

           cols_cs = cumsum(cols)
           cols_cat = ( reduce(vcat, xs[ (1:cols[i]) .+ (cols_cs[i] - cols[i]) ]) for i in 1:length(cols) )
           reduce(hcat, cols_cat)
       end
